Owensboro Municipal Utilities

                                       Elmer Smith Station / Cavin Treatment Plant 

                                                    Risk Management Plan

                                          EPA Facility Identifier:  100000132732

                                                        Executive Summary



The Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990 added Section 112(r) to the CAA, which mandated the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish a regulatory program to prevent serious chemical accidents that may potentially affect public health and the environment.  The CAA makes it clear that facilities that handle hazardous substances bear the primary responsibility for ensuring their safe use.  This statutory mandate required EPA to establish a list of regulated substances as well as propose elements of an accidental release prevention program.



Under the requirements of Section 112(r), stationary sources (facilities) must identify and assess their chemical hazards and implement certain activities that are designed to reduce the likelihood and severity of accidental chemical releases. Also, facilities must submit a risk management plan (RMP) that summarizes these activities, and the plans will be available to state and local governments, the public and other stakeholders. The hazard assessment data disclosed by facilities can be used by local emergency planning committees (LEPCs) and other local response agencies to improve community emergency response planning. Also, the information in the risk management plan gives citizens the opportunity to work with industry to reduce risks to the community from chemical accidents.



The final RMP rule spells out requirements for the following basic components of a risk management program that regulated facilities must implement:



    A hazard assessment program that identifies and analyzes the potential onsite and offsite

impacts of worst-case and alternative accidental release scenarios of regulated substances, and includes documentation of five-year accident histories involving regulated substances;



    A prevention program that covers operating procedures, maintenance, training, management of change, process safety information, etc., for operations involving regulated substances;



    An emergency response program to mitigate any accidental releases that occur; and



    An overall system to manage the development and implementation of a risk management program.



The Cavin Water Treatment Plant submitted an initial Rick Management Plan Registration in June 1999 for the storage and processing of chlorine in its water chlorination process.  The Cavin Plant is owned and operated by Owensboro Municipal Utilities with the NAICS Code Number 22131.  The Cavin Plant received the EPA Facility Identifier Number 100000132732.



In July 2003, the Elmer Smith Station (NAICS Code 221112) added anhydrous ammonia to the station in quantities greater than the RMP threshold quantity.  As such, the Elmer Smith Station is submitted RMP registration data. 



The Cavin Plant and Elmer Smith Station are both owned and operated by Owensboro Municipal Utilities. In addition, the two plants are contiguous properties.  Based on definition of stationary source, the two plants will be covered under one RMP Plan registration.  The two properties are considered a single stationary source under 40 CFR 68 as they meet the four main criteria:



     Stationary activity which belongs to same industrial group (NAICS Codes 221A?)

     Located on one or more contiguous properties

     Under the control of a common entity

     Has the potential for an critical release of a regulated quantity of a RMP chemical.



A description of the regulated substances handled: The Elmer Smith Station / Cavin Plant is an electric power generation station and a water treatment facility.  Anhydrous ammonia (the threshold

quantity is 10,000 pounds; the site has 300,000 pounds) chlorine (the threshold quantity is 2,500 pounds; the site has potentially 20,000 pounds) and are the only RMP regulated substances, at this stationary source, above the threshold quantity levels established by EPA. 



Anhydrous ammonia, stored in two 30,000 gallon storage tanks, is used in the SCR and SNCR systems to reduce nitrous oxides emissions. Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a colorless gas at ambient temperature or pressure; it is, however, stored as a liquid under pressure.  The gas is less dense than air, but when liquid ammonia is released it may aerosolize and behave as a dense gas.  The effects of ammonia inhalation range from irritation to severe respiratory injuries to death.  Ammonia is self-alarming; its strong odor is noticeable at concentrations above 50 ppm; concentration that is immediately dangerous to life and health (IDLH) is 300 ppm.  In general, people will not remain in the presence of ammonia so that the primary threat is to people who are unable to flee.



The Cavin Plant uses chlorine to treat water for eventual potable usage in quantities requiring an RMP (under present EPA regulation).  This process is for the chlorination of drinking water supplies.  Chlorine is a dense, nonflammable greenish-yellow gas with a bleach-like odor.  It is corrosive and severely irritating to all tissue.  The chlorine reduces bacterial and algal growth. The water treatment systems consist of a one ton chlorine container and associated piping, valves, and chlorine feed equipment that dissolves chlorine into the circulated water. 



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:  This facility complies with requirements for hazardous materials use, and it is Owensboro Municipal Utilities' (OMU) policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is OMU's policy to notify the Daviess County LEPC and respond to the emergency.  A site spe

cific emergency plan has been developed to address emergencies.



The worst case scenario, Anhydrous Ammonia:  As required by EPA, the worst case scenario evaluates the failure of one of the 30,000 gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tanks when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% at 60F), resulting in a dense vapor cloud.  According to ALOHA program(an EPA approved modeling program), the distance with EPA established concentrations of concern is approximately 5.4 miles.  The 5.4 mile radius includes an estimated residential population of 60,312 people, a recreational area, a school, a hospital and office or industrial areas.



The worst case scenario, Chlorine: As required by EPA, the worst case scenario evaluates the failure of the one ton chlorine container when filled to the greatest amount allowed (88% at 60F), resulting in a dense vapor cloud.  According to ALOHA program (an EPA approved modeling program), the distance with EPA established concentrations of concern is approximately 3.0 miles.  The 3.0 mile radius includes an estimated residential population of 1,634 people, a recreational area, a school, and office or industrial areas.



Five-year accident history: The Cavin Plant has not had an accident in the past five years involving chlorine that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. Similarly, the Elmer Smith Station has not had an accident in the past five years involving anhydrous ammonia.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  This stationary source complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The hazardous materials systems are designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with Chlorine Institute guidelines, manufacturer specifications, best management practices, and state law.  The Elmer Smith Station is required to comply with the most stringent EPA RMP and OSHA preventio

n programs and is designed and operated in accordance with ANSI K61.1 guidelines, manufacturers guidelines, and applicable State codes.



The emergency response program: In the event of an emergency involving the chlorine or anhydrous ammonia systems, it is OMU's policy for the operator to evacuate the immediate area.  If any release is likely to impact off site, the local emergency services will be notified. OMU employees are trained to use self-contained breathing equipment and have taken OSHA worker right-to-know training.  A contract response team is available to respond to releases.
